user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_get_timestamp:
```c
unsigned long long metal_get_timestamp(void)
{
	unsigned long long t = 0;
	struct timespec tp;
	int r;

	r = clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &tp);
	if (r == -1) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "clock_gettime failed!\n");
		return t;
	}
	t = tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S);
	t += tp.tv_nsec;

	return t;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_get_timestamp:
#define NS_PER_S (1000*1000*1000)
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function metal_get_timestamp has no formal parameters, so local variable definitions and modifications (unsigned long long t = 0; struct timespec tp; int r; the assignments to t and r, the arithmetic t = tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S); t += tp.tv_nsec; and the return t;) cannot violate Rule 17.8 and therefore do not need investigation. The NS_PER_S macro is a compile-time constant and not a function parameter. The only locations that could involve modification of function parameters are calls/macros that introduce parameters in other functions or handlers; those calls/definitions are listed above for investigation.
